summary: animal studies were carried out in accordance with the UK Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act of 1986 and the Codes of Practice for the Housing and Care of Animals used in Scientific Procedures 1989. all animals were surgically implanted intraperitoneally with a Remo 200 device (Remo Technologies Ltd, Salisbury, UK) the frozen stock of B. pseudomallei was recovered on to LB-agar plates with 5% glycerol (LBG) and incubated at 37 °C for 48 h. then incubated at 37 °C with shaking at 180 rpm for 24 h. suspension was serially diluted to the appropriate concentration. s were subcultured onto LB-agar plates for B. pseudomallei or LBG for B. mallei and incubated at 37 °C for 24 or 48 h respectively. Counts are expressed as cfu/g of tissue or cfu/ml of blood. sections were dewaxed, rehydrated and then treated in hydrogen peroxide 3% (v/v) the tissue sections were then pretreated for antigen retrieval by either enzymatic digestion with pronase XIV (0.05% w/v pronase XIV 5.2 U/mg; Sigma 9.c) the sections were then microwaved in citric acid buffer (2.1 g citric acid; Fisher Scientific, Loughborough, Leicestershire, UK) the sections were incubated for 30 min at room temperature with ABC. the signal was detected using 3,30-diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride (DAB) the sections were lightly counterstained with Mayer's haematoxylin (Surgipath, Peterborough, UK) for 5 min. Bacterial capsular antigen was detected using a B. pseudomallei antibody (3VIE5) that has shown cross-reactivity with B. mallei. controls included sequential sections with an isotype control for each primary antibody. all animals were surgically implanted intraperitoneally with a Remo 200 device (Remo Technologies Ltd, Salisbury, UK) to record core body temperature (Tc) data were transmitted from the devices at 30 s intervals to local placed antennas and relayed to receivers. the frozen stock of B. mallei was recovered on to LB-agar plates with 5% glycerol (LBG) and incubated at 37 °C for 48 h before inoculation into nutrient broth. then further incubated at 37 °C with shaking at 180 rpm for 24 h. Thin sections (4 m) were cut and stained with haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) for histopathological analysis. a scoring system was established to allow semi-quantitative comparison. sections were then microwaved in citric acid buffer (2.1 g citric acid) for 18 min at 100 °C, 90% effect (780 W) or microwaved in dako high pH 9.0 buffer for 10 min. primary antibody cross-reactivity with tissue constituents was prevented using 1.5% normal serum block applied to the sections for 20 min. the sections were lightly counterstained with Mayer's haematoxylin (Surgipath, Peterborough, UK) for 5 min, dehydrated in absolute alcohol and cleared in xylene before being coverslipped. evident in the liver, spleen and lymph nodes. melioidosis varies from acute sepsis with fever, bacteraemia and primary or secondary pneumonia to chronic localised infection associated with abscesses and ulcerations, to latent infection. the most prevalent natural route of exposure is believed to be inoculation through cuts or skin abrasions. the subcutaneous route of challenge was used in the marmosets to mimic systemic disease. in humans, primary cutaneous melioidosis results in a localised infection causing single lesions ranging from ulcers to boils, pustules or even erythematous lesions. bacteraemia is a common complication of primary cutaneous melioidosis. marmoset models of glanders and melioidosis are reproducibly lethal at selected challenge doses. the time to the onset of clinical disease in humans is variable, ranging from 24 h to 62 years. in the marmosets, particularly melioidosis, the marmoset models acute, lethal disease that would serve as a stringent model for the medical countermeasure. the marmoset has been previously used to assess medical countermeasures; a vaccine has been tested for Lassa fever (Lukashevicha et al. 2008) and the efficacy of
